reviewText: I cannot add anything to the other reviews!! These films are gems !!! If you are a Sherlock fan you must see these !!!!  And to believe these were done in 1957 is truly amazing. They could have been done far more recently.  Watson is perfect, Sherlock took about 15 minutes to get used to and then we adored him. Then we fell for all of the actors and characters !!  Moriarty is the scariest Moriarty I have ever seen, sinister, real, perfect.  Does have English subtitles of course. The other reviews go into more depth and I would just be repeating so I won't.  But read them, know how terrific this set is.  So if you are a fan of cinema or Sherlock don't hesitate !!!!
Title: N/A

reviewText: The fact that 'Sherlock' was awarded an MBE by the English Queen for services to English Literature speaks volumes by itself. A brilliant series of films based on the works of Arthur Conan Doyle, but which do not follow them too closely and a fair bit of licence and juxtaposition of story-lines is obvious with some episodes containing elements from several of Holmes adventures. An example of the licence taken is that Doctor Watson is not the somewhat bumbling man several years senior to Holmes, as portrayed in the series in which Basil Rathbone starred as Holmes, he is instead a very young and suave gentleman as originally envisaged by Doyle.The opening theme music is 'Once Heard Never Forgotten' and is instantly related in one's mind with this series !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!My Russian born wife tells me that clocks were set and house routines devised around the screening times of this excellent series when it was first shown many years ago in the Soviet Union. Hearing the first notes of the theme music meant that one stopped whatever one was doing at the time and sat in front of the box for the duration.
summary: The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes and Doctor Watson
Title: N/A

reviewText: I'd heard so much about this Russian version of Sherlock Holmes and Doctor John Watson from friends in England that I had to finally order it after watching a few clips on YouTube.  I definitely recommend it to all diehard fans, but I also recommend buying the subtitled version rather than the dubbed set that I've seen sold.  You need to hear the genuine delight in their roles and how the actors truly like each other.  Quite frankly, this series may be as brilliant as the Grenada series with Jeremy Brett.  Definitley in my top favorite renditions of Holmes and Watson.
summary: Has become one of my favorites

reviewText: Every generation has its favorite Homes and Watson, ever since Doyle and Paget collaborated on the Strand publications. Few are as true to the original as this Russian set, splendidly remastered visually and sonically. If you can bear subtitles, or know the Holmes canon by memory, this may be the the most imaginative yet faithful rendition of a generous handful of the most beloved Homes adventures. The acting is outstanding, as the best Russian acting always is. But many who know this set from the late 70's consider Livanov the definitive Holmes. I was raised on Rathbone, so of course those wonderful films are nostalgic; but no one can argue they are faithful to Doyle's original. I realize several generations have now become accustomed to Jeremy Brett, whose eccentricity and camp increased exponentially over the series. I have no reason to buy the whole of Brett; but every reason to pay the high tariff for this Russian masterworks. You will not regret a penny of your purchase.A word about Benedict Cumberbatch and the new "Sherlock" on BBC. First of all, go right out and buy seasons 1 and 2 -- with these caveats. It is NOT Doyle's Homes, it is not even Doyle's plots; but it is outstandingly conceived as an update with "analogous" stories told in 90-minute movies. I love and highly recommend the series. But it is a completely new approach, new genre; full of wonderful obscure references and scenes culled from the entire Strand series -- as are the Russian films. "Sherlock" creates its own world, contemporary, eschewing Victorian atmosphere and the deep social culture "The Baker Street Irregulars" Club adore. The Russian films are so true to the original, even though shot in some places which could only exist architecturally in the Tolstoy. Nonetheless, the time period matches Victorian England, the feel and flavor are immaculate, and the performances are towering -- what we would called Oscar Nominated. I have read that Britain's Queen Elizabeth II conferred an honorary CBE on this series, and that the most prominent display of a depiction of Holmes in a museum dedicated to interpretations, features not Gillette but the Russian Livanov. Offical Praise indeed from the Queen of England who now reigns longer than Victoria.For those of you raised exclusively on the wonderfully fun but neurotic excesses of Jeremy Brett -- histrionic without depth of thought -- this set will come as a revelation and a treasure. It may even send the new generation of Homes' admirers back to the original novels, stories and adventures to be found these days in a wonderful huge Illustrated 2-volume set by Bill Baring-Gould, and in a facsimile of the complete Strand publications.
summary: Absolutely Magnificent Set of Russian Films
